animalOfTheDay.name: tarsier
facts: Tarsiers have the largest eyes relative to body size of any mammal.
They can rotate their heads nearly 180 degrees in each direction.
Tarsiers are the only entirely carnivorous primates, eating insects, lizards, and small birds.
They communicate using ultrasonic frequencies beyond human hearing.

calendar.name: starfish
facts: Starfish are not fish; they are echinoderms, related to sea urchins and sand dollars.
They can regenerate lost arms, and some species can even regrow an entire body from a single arm.
Starfish have no brain or blood; instead, they use a water vascular system to move their tube feet.
There are over 2,000 species of starfish, found in all the world's oceans.

calendar.name: stick insect
facts: Stick insects are masters of camouflage, resembling twigs or leaves.
Some species can reproduce without males through parthenogenesis.
They can regenerate lost limbs when they molt.
Stick insects are among the longest insects, with some species reaching over 2 feet in length.

calendar.name: stingray
facts: Their stingers are modified scales and can deliver venom, but they only use them in self-defense.
Stingrays are closely related to sharks and have skeletons made of cartilage, not bone.
They use electroreceptors to detect the electrical signals of prey hidden in the sand.
Stingrays 'fly' through the water by flapping their pectoral fins like wings.

calendar.name: stoat
facts: Stoats are small but fierce predators that can take down prey much larger than themselves.
In cold climates, they turn white in winter and are called ermine.
Stoats perform a hypnotic 'dance' to confuse prey before attacking.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting in trees and water.

calendar.name: swordfish
facts: Swordfish have a specialized organ that warms their eyes and brain, improving their vision in cold water.
Swordfish can dive to depths of over 1,800 feet in search of food.
They can swim at speeds up to 60 mph, making them one of the fastest fish.
Their sword-like bill is used to slash at prey, stunning or injuring them.

calendar.name: tamarin
facts: They often give birth to twins, which is unusual for primates.
Tamarin monkeys are among the smallest primates, some weighing less than a pound.
Tamarins have claw-like nails instead of flat nails like other monkeys.
They communicate through a variety of high-pitched vocalizations.

calendar.name: tarsier
facts: They communicate using ultrasonic frequencies beyond human hearing.
Tarsiers are the only entirely carnivorous primates, eating insects, lizards, and small birds.
Tarsiers have the largest eyes relative to body size of any mammal.
They can rotate their heads nearly 180 degrees in each direction.

randomAnimals.name: sea cucumber
facts: Sea cucumbers can eject their internal organs as a defense mechanism and later regenerate them.
They breathe through their anus by pumping water in and out of their respiratory tree.
Some species can liquefy their bodies to squeeze through small spaces.
They play a crucial role in ocean ecosystems by recycling nutrients on the seafloor.

randomAnimals.name: red fox
facts: A group of foxes is called a skulk or leash.
They use over 40 different sounds to communicate.
Red foxes have excellent hearing and can locate prey under snow.
They're more closely related to dogs than cats.

randomAnimals.name: sea otter
facts: Sea otters hold hands while sleeping to prevent drifting apart.
They play a crucial role in maintaining kelp forest ecosystems by controlling sea urchin populations.
They use rocks as tools to crack open shellfish while floating on their backs.
Sea otters have the densest fur of any animal, with up to 1 million hairs per square inch.
